page.title: 11LEAD MINING
page.content: From the 18th century onwards the local mines in Scordale were taken over by the London Lead Company. This Quaker-run business was concerned for the moral and social welfare of the miners and their families and Hilton and Murton thrived. Housing was good by the standards of the time, in Hilton water was supplied to pumps and troughs. The company arranged schooling for the children, too.(Ref. .A.Raistrick,Two Centuries of Industrial Welfare,1938). The mines closed in 1960 but fortunately records and photographs have been kept by Dorothy and the late Edgar Hinchliffe. Edgar Hinchcliffe is also the author of the History of Appleby Grammar School and has contributed to major research into the Washington family and to Saint John Boste.(see Appleby entry in Domesday '86)
